procedure_1.csv.text:
You will see the two boxes with locks
These boxes are linked with the same set of videos
However, one box opens at the same delay (3 seconds) while other opens at a variable delay (1,3,6 seconds).

Open the locks to see a video
You can choose freely which locks to open

Click on the lock you want to unlock

Wait until a lock has disappeared before you click on another lock

You cannot change your mind about which box you want to open once you've clicked on a lock

Click on "Proceed" to save your data.

You will receive a debrief of this study in an email.

You've completed this part of the study!

Please proceed, and DO NOT CLOSE THE WINDOW before you have received confirmation that the data has been successfully submitted

cam_info:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher/Student: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk | Supervisor/Chief investigator: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

We would like to invite you to take part in a research study about factors which may play a role in anxiety in adults with and without autism. Before you begin, we would like you to understand why the research is being done and what it involves for you.

What is the purpose of this study?

I am a postgraduate student at the University of Nottingham studying for an MSc in Mental Health research and practice. I am conducting this study for my research project which will allow me to complete and gain my MSc qualification. The aim of this research is to investigate intolerance of uncertainty, sensory sensitivity, and anxiety in adults who do and do not identify as having autism. Specifically, I aim to investigate how varying levels of intolerance of uncertainty, and sensory sensitivity may (or may not) influence anxiety, and how this may differ between adults with and without autism. We cannot promise the study will help you but the information we get from this study may help us gain a deeper understanding of the role(s) intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity may play in anxiety, both in typical and autism-identifying adults. This could help in development of targeted intervention for co-occurring anxiety in autism.

Why have I been invited?

I am asking adults (over 18 years old) to complete this online study. You have been identified because you responded to an earlier invitation to take part in this research. Ideally, I am hoping to recruit around 140 participants for this study (70 participants who identify as autistic and 70 who do not).

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part, you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form when directed to the online study. You may change your mind about being involved at any time or decline to discuss a particular question. You are free to withdraw at any point before or during the study without giving a reason. You may also withdraw after the study, but if you wish to do so this must be done within 3 days following completion. If you wish to withdraw, please contact the student researcher with your participant code (which you will be assigned when you do the study), and all of your data will then be removed. To safeguard your rights, we will use the minimum personally-identifiable information possible. There will also be an opportunity to enter a prize draw for taking part in the study of £25, and there will be 8 prizes available. If you wish to enter, you will need to provide the researcher with your email address so that you can be contacted if you win.

What will I be asked to do?

If you decide to take part, you will be asked to complete an online study. Before beginning the study, you will be asked to read and sign a consent form. You will then be provided with a short form to provide demographic information such as your gender and age. You will not be required to disclose your name or personal information; you will have a unique identification code generated in the event your data needs to be accessed later should you wish to withdraw. You will then be required to complete the study. You will be presented with self-report questionnaires regarding autistic traits, anxiety, sensory sensitivity, and intolerance of uncertainty. Following this, you will be required to complete 2 interactive behavioural tasks; one will be a “sensory sensitivity” task, the other will be an “intolerance of uncertainty” task. The study may take up to 90 minutes, therefore collection of data may be split into two or three shorter sessions to work through all the questionnaires/tasks.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be used by the researcher to complete their postgraduate research project. A summary of the study’s findings will be available upon request following completion of the study in September 2022. Data belonging to anybody who agrees to participate in this research will remain strictly anonymous. When your data is recorded, you will be assigned a unique ID code to correspond to your study responses; none of your personal or identifiable information will be exposed. Your data will not be shared with any third parties, and your identity and responses will not be directly or indirectly identifiable from any research findings presented in the final report. All data will be collected and stored in accordance with the University of Nottingham’s Code of Conduct and Research Ethics and data protection regulations. Following completion of this project, any raw data collected for the purpose of this research will be securely stored by the University for 7 years. Data will not be stored anywhere else; after this time all data will be appropriately removed. If you enter the prize draw, your email address will be protected and securely stored separate to any data obtained from the study, and it will be removed as soon as the winners of the draw have been contacted.

Are there any possible disadvantages or risks in taking part?

We believe there are no known risks associated with this research study; however, as with any online activity the risk of a breach is always possible. We will do everything possible to ensure your answers in this study will remain anonymous. We don’t expect there to be any disadvantages or risks to taking part. In the unlikely event that it does give rise to any concerns for you, we advise you to discuss these with a trained professional, such as your general practitioner. Other areas to get support include the Samaritans, contactable on 116 123, or Mind, a mental health charity, contactable on 0300 123 3393. There is also the National Autistic Society; they do not have a direct helpline, but you will be able to find contact details for support and enquiries at https://www.autism.org.uk/what-we-do/help-and-support, where you can also find contact details for support groups in your local area.

Data Protection

We will follow ethical and legal practice and all information will be handled in confidence. Under UK Data Protection laws the University is the Data Controller (legally responsible for the data security) and the Chief Investigator of this study (named above) is the Data Custodian (manages access to the data). This means we are responsible for looking after your information and using it properly. Your rights to access, change or move your information are limited as we need to manage your information in specific ways to comply with certain laws and for the research to be reliable and accurate. To safeguard your rights we will use the minimum personally–identifiable information possible. You can find out more about how we use your information and to read our privacy notice at: https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/utilities/privacy.aspx We would like your permission to use anonymised data in future studies, and to share our research data (e.g. in online databases) with other researchers in other Universities and organisations both inside and outside the European Union. This would be used for research in health and social care. Sharing research data is important to allow peer scrutiny, re-use (and therefore avoiding duplication of research) and to understand the bigger picture in particular areas of research. All personal information that could identify you will be removed or changed before information is shared with other researchers or results are made public. The raw data collected for the study will be saved on the RedCap storage platform for University of Nottingham and University of Reading and will be accessible to the named researchers and collaborators. They may also be looked at by authorised people from regulatory organisations to check that the study is being carried out correctly. All will have a duty of confidentiality to you as a research participant and we will do our best to meet this duty. At the end of the project, all raw data will be kept securely by the University under the terms of its data protection policy after which it will be disposed of securely. The data will not be kept elsewhere. If you have any questions or concerns, please don’t hesitate to ask. We can be contacted before and after your participation at the email addresses above.

What if there is a problem?

If you have any queries or complaints, please contact the student’s supervisor/chief investigator in the first instance. If this does not resolve your query, please write to the Administrator to the Division of Psychiatry & Applied Psychology’s Research Ethics Sub-Committee adrian.pantry@nottingam.ac.uk who will pass your query to the Chair of the Committee. If you remain unhappy and wish to complain formally, you should then contact the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences Ethics Committee Administrator, Faculty Hub, Medicine and Health Sciences, E41, E Floor, Medical School, Queen’s Medical Centre Campus, Nottingham University Hospitals, Nottingham, NG7 2UH or via E-mail: FMHS-ResearchEthics@nottingham.ac.uk
I have read the information sheet and I am happy to continue
cam_consent:
Title of project: Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of 
anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk |
Supervisor: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, 
University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk
Please select the following statements if you agree with them. Please feel free to withdraw at any point.
1. Have you read and understood the Participant Information?

2. Do you agree to take part in an experiment investigating intolerance of uncertainty and 
sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in adults with and without autism?

3. Do you know how to contact the researcher if you have questions
about this study?

4. Do you understand that you are free to withdraw from the study
without giving a reason within 3 days following completion, and that after 
this time it may not be technically possible to withdraw your data?

5. Do you give permission for your data from this study to be shared with 
other researchers in the future provided that your anonymity is protected?

6. Do you understand that non-identifiable data from this study including 
quotations might be used in academic research reports or publications?
7. I confirm that I am 18 years old or over.

If you would like a summary of the research findings please insert your email address in 
this text box.

If you would like to enter the prize draw to win £25, please insert your email address in this 
text box.

autism_quotient: Please choose to from the scale ranging from 1=ÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂnot at all characteristic of meÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ to 5=ÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂentirely characteristic of meÃÂÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂÃÂÃÂ.
Uncertainty stops me from having a strong opinion.
Being uncertain means that a person is disorganized.
It's unfair having no guarantees in life.
My mind can't be relaxed if I don't know what will happen tomorrow.
Uncertainty makes me uneasy, anxious, or stressed.
It frustrates me not having all the information I need.
Uncertainty keeps me from living a full life.
One should always look ahead so as to avoid surprises.
A small unforeseen event can spoil everything, even with the best planning.
When it's time to act, uncertainty paralyses me.
Being uncertain means that I am not first rate.
When I am uncertain, I can't go forward.
When I am uncertain, I can't function very well.
Unlike me, others seem to know where they are going with their lives.
Uncertainty makes me vulnerable, unhappy, or sad.
I always want to know what the future has in store for me.
I can't stand being taken by surprise.
The smallest doubt can stop me from acting.
I should be able to organize everything in advance.
Being uncertain means that I lack confidence.
I think it's unfair that other people seem to be sure about their future.
Uncertainty keeps me from sleeping soundly.
I must get away from all uncertain situations.
The ambiguities in life stress me.
I can't stand being undecided about my future.

cam_debrief:
Debrief form

Thank you so much for participating in this study. This study aims to explore how worry may affect the day to day behaviour and choices we make. Literature suggests that the worry experienced by people with autism might be different from worry experienced by other people. It is proposed that social difficulties, sensory sensitivity, or uncertainty might be the significant cause of worry for people with autism but not those without autism. In this study, we are exploring if these factors can reliably predict worry in people with autism but not in people with worry without autism. We believe this study would help shaping differential interventions for people experiencing different kinds of worry. If you would like to know more about the project, please contact the lead investigator.

If you would like to withdraw your consent, please contact the lead investigator in next 3 days. After 3 days of the participation we will not be able to delete your data.

Contact for Further Information
Dr Indu Dubey
Lecturer in Psychology
Room 0.35, Hawthorn Building
Division of Psychology,
School of Applied Social Sciences,
De Montfort University,
Leicester,
UK
Phone: 0116 366 4401
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue

withdrawal_code = '';
var characters       = 'ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789';
var charactersLength = characters.length;
for ( var i = 0; i < 16; i++ ) {
  withdrawal_code += characters.charAt(Math.floor(Math.random() * charactersLength));
}
Trial.set("withdrawal_code",withdrawal_code);
$("#withdrawal_code").val(withdrawal_code);
Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},100);
</script>

health_anxiety_inventory.csv: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:

Each question is this section consists of a group of four statements. Please read each group of statements carefully and then select the one which best describes your feelings, over the past six months. Identify the statement by ringing the letter next to it, i.e. if you think that statement (a) is correct, ring statement (a) ; it may be that more than one statement applies, in which case, please ring any that are applicable.
I do not worry about my health.| I occasionally worry about my health. | I spend much of my time worrying about my health | I spend most of my time worrying about my health.

I notice aches/pains less than most other people (of my age). | I notice aches/pains as much as most other people (of my age). |  I notice aches/pains more than most other people (of my age).| I am aware of aches/pains in my body all the time.

As a rule I am not aware of bodily sensations or changes. | Sometimes I am aware of bodily sensations or changes. | I am often aware of bodily sensations or changes. I am constantly aware of bodily sensations or changes.

Resisting thoughts of illness is never a problem. |  Most of the time I can resist thoughts of illness. |  I try to resist thoughts of illness but am often unable to do so. |  Thoughts of illness are so strong that I no longer even try to resist them.

As a rule I am not afraid that I have a serious illness | I am sometimes afraid that I have a serious illness. | I am often afraid that I have a serious illness. | I am always afraid that I have a serious illness.

I do not have images (mental pictures) of myself being ill. | I occasionally have images of myself being ill. | I frequently have images of myself being ill. |  I constantly have images of myself being ill.

I do not have any difficulty taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | I sometimes have difficulty taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | I often have difficulty in taking my mind off thoughts about my health. | Nothing can take my mind off thoughts about my health.

I am lastingly relieved if my doctor tells me there is nothing wrong. | I am initially relieved but the worries sometimes return later. |  I am initially relieved but the worries always return later. |  I am not relieved if my doctor tells me there is nothing wrong.

If I hear about an illness I sometimes think I have it myself. |  If I hear about an illness I often think I have it myself. |  If I hear about an illness I always think I have it myself. | If I hear about an illness I never think I have it myself

If I have a bodily sensation or change I often wonder what it means. |  If I have a bodily sensation or change I always wonder what it means. |  If I have a bodily sensation or change I must know what it means. | If I have a bodily sensation or change I rarely wonder what it mean

I usually feel at fairly low risk for developing a serious illness. |  I usually feel at moderate risk for developing a serious illness. |  I usually feel at high risk for developing a serious illness. | I usually feel at very low risk for developing a serious illness
I sometimes think I have a serious illness. |  I often think I have a serious illness. | I usually think that I am seriously ill. | I never think I have a serious illness

If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I donÕt find it difficult to think about other things |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I sometimes find it difficult to think about other things. |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I often find it difficult to think about other things. |  If I notice an unexplained bodily sensation I always find it difficult to think about other things.

My family/friends would say I do not worry enough about my health. | My family’friends would say I have a normal attitude to my health. |  My family’friends would say I worry too much about my health. |  My family’friends would say I am a hypochondriac

For the following questions, please think about what it might be like if you had a serious illness of a type which particularly concerns you (such as heart disease, cancer, multiple sclerosis and so on). Obviously you cannot know for definite what it would be like ; please give your best estimate of what you think might happen, basing your estimate on what you know about yourself and serious illness in general.

IfI had a serious illness I would still be able to enjoy things in my life quite a lot. |  IfI had a serious illness I would still be able to enjoy things in my life a little. |  IfI had a serious illness I would be almost completely unable to enjoy things in my life. |  IfI had a serious illness I would be completely unable to enjoy life at all.

IfI developed a serious illness there is a good chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. |  IfI developed a serious illness there is a moderate chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. | If I developed a serious illness there is a very small chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me. | If I developed a serious illness there is no chance that modern medicine would be able to cure me.

A serious illness would ruin some aspects of my life | A serious illness would ruin many aspects of my life. |  A serious illness would ruin almost every aspect of my life. |  A serious illness would ruin every aspect of my life.

If I had a serious illness I would not feel that I had lost my dignity | If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had lost a little of my dignity. |  If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had lost quite a lot of my dignity. |  If I had a serious illness I would feel that I had totally lost my dignity.

procedure_1.csv.text:
You will see an image on the screen. The image will stay on the screen only for a brief duration. After that there will be a wait for nearly 6 seconds.
During this time, you can either look at the blank screen or look at the same image again by pressing the space bar.
Every time you press the space bar the image will reappear on the screen for a brief period. You are free to keep pressing the space bar to look at the image as many times as you like in those 6 seconds.
After 6 seconds a new image will appear on the screen and you would have the same choice again to either look at the blank screen or press the space bar to look at the that image again.
This is the start of approach phase.

You will see an image on the screen. The image will stay on the screen for nearly 6 seconds.
During this time, you can either look at the image or remove it by pressing the space bar. Every time you press the space bar the image will disappear for a brief period.
You are free to keep pressing the space bar to avoid looking at the image as many times as you like in those 6 seconds.
After 6 seconds a new image will appear on the screen and you would have the same choice again to either look at the image or press the space bar to remove it.
This is the start of avoidance phase.

procedure_2.csv.text:
You will see an image on the screen. The image will stay on the screen only for a brief duration. After that there will be a wait for nearly 6 seconds.
During this time, you can either look at the blank screen or look at the same image again by pressing the space bar.
Every time you press the space bar the image will reappear on the screen for a brief period. You are free to keep pressing the space bar to look at the image as many times as you like in those 6 seconds.
After 6 seconds a new image will appear on the screen and you would have the same choice again to either look at the blank screen or press the space bar to look at the that image again.
This is the start of avoidance phase.

You will see an image on the screen. The image will stay on the screen for nearly 6 seconds.

You are free to keep pressing the space bar to avoid looking at the image as many times as you like in those 6 seconds.
After 6 seconds a new image will appear on the screen and you would have the same choice again to either look at the image or press the space bar to remove it.
This is the start of approach phase.

aa_info.csv:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Who is doing this research?

The research will be conducted by Thujageni Nimalraj, a third year Psychology Student studying for a BSc (Hons) Psychology at De Montfort University, Leicester.

What is the research about?

I am conducting an online study using a questionnaire and experimental based design, looking at social anxiety and autistic traits in typical adults and how this influences social avoidant behaviour.

Why am I being invited to participate?

For this study, we are looking for participants who are over the age of 18 and participants who have normal or corrected to normal vision.

What are you asking of me?

I am asking you to take part in an online study with three questionnaires paired with a task lasting about 45 minutes and I will ask you some questions about social anxiety and autistic traits paired with an approach-avoidance task.

What if I want to drop out?

If you wish to drop out at any stage during participation in the study, you are free to do so and will not be asked to give a reason. You can withdraw by closing the internet browser and contacting the researcher. If you wish to withdraw your data after the study you can do this, without any impending consequences, up to two weeks after participation. Should you wish to withdraw your data in this time, please contact the researcher using the details provided below and quote your unique participant ID.

Will the information I give you be kept confidential?

All information collected will be treated with the strictest confidence throughout the study. The information obtained in the study will be anonymous and IP addresses will not be recorded. Data will be stored securely and at the end of my dissertation it will be handed over to my supervisor for safekeeping. Once my final grade has been confirmed, data will be disposed of securely or, in the case of publication, anonymous non-identifiable data will be kept for a longer period of time in-line with institutional and publisher requirements.

What if I am upset by anything during the course of the study?

If this happens, you might like to take a break, or if you prefer, you can decide to end your participation and withdraw from the study at that point. If you decide to withdraw, you will be taken to the debrief page. The debrief page contains information about appropriate sources of support which you can access if there is anything about your own life experiences you wish to talk about in confidence.

Who will have access to the data?

The researcher, the researcher’s supervisor, markers from the Division of Psychology, and possibly an external examiner will have access to the data. There is also a possibility that the results could be written up for publication (e.g., in academic journals etc.). In this situation, only relevant researchers will have access to the anonymous data, and the anonymous data might be uploaded to an online repository. In all instances, anonymity of individual participants will be assured.

Who will see the finished report?

All data in the finished report will be presented in the form of group statistics. The final report will be seen by the researcher’s supervisor and a second marker from the Division of Psychology and may been seen by an external examiner. In addition, the completed report may also be made available to future De Montfort University students for teaching purposes.

Who has given approval for this study?

Approval for this study has been granted by the De Montfort University, Division of Psychology, Ethics Management Committee.

What if something goes wrong? / Who can I complain to?

If you have a complaint regarding anything to do with this study, you can approach either the lead researcher, or the researcher’s supervisor; supervisor contact details are given below.

Is there anyone I can talk to about the study before I take part?

Before taking part in the study you can email me with any questions you have using the contact details below. If you wish to talk to someone else about my study then please feel free to contact my project supervisor.

I know a friend who may be interested; can s/he participate in your study?

Yes certainly as long as your friend meets the criteria mentioned above. Your friend can contact me directly to discuss the study if they wish. My contact details are given below.

If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact me. My contact details are as follows:



Researcher’s contact details:

Thujageni Nimalraj
Email: thujageni.nimalraj@my365.dmu.ac.uk

Supervisor's contact details

Dr Indu Dubey
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk
De Montfort University
Division of Psychology
Hawthorn Building Room No. HB0.35
The Gateway
Leicester LE1 9BH
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue
aa_consent.csv: Please select the following statements if you agree with them. Please feel free to withdraw at any point.

1. I am at least 18 years of age and I voluntarily agree to participate in a research project conducted and outlined to me by Thujageni Nimalraj, an undergraduate student studying for a BSc (Hons) in Psychology at De Montfort University.
2. I have read the information sheet and understand that this research is being conducted as part of a third-year research project.

3. I acknowledge that Thujageni Nimalraj has explained the task to me fully. I have been informed that I may withdraw from participation without prejudice or penalty if I so wish and my data will be appropriately destroyed. I have been informed that withdrawal after two weeks will not be possible.
4. The researcher has offered to answer any questions concerning the research procedure and I have been provided with contact details for both the researcher and their supervisor.

5. I understand I will be fully protected in accordance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), and in compliance with British Psychological Society ethical guidelines and that my data will be kept confidential and anonymous until it is securely destroyed.

6. I understand my name and any personal details will be anonymised in any report concerning this study, though I agree that any of the anonymised data I provide may be used in the researcher’s report and possibly used for publication in academic journals
7. I understand that in case the anonymous data is used for publication, the anonymous data will be available to the relevant researchers, and could be uploaded to an online research repository.
8. I am willing for my anonymised data to be used for teaching purposes at De Montfort University.  (Please note that is possible to participate in the research even if you do not agree to this).
9. I am at least 18 years old and I confirm that I have read all of the above and give my consent to participate in the study.

autism_quotient: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.

aa_debrief.csv:
Debrief form

Thank you for taking part in this study. This study focuses on the influence of high social anxiety, low social motivation and high autistic traits in typical adults and the possible links to high social avoidance. This research study aims to explore this by evaluating if low social approach is in typical adults can be predicted by their social anxiety or by their autistic traits. Also, the research aims to see whether low social motivation in typical adults would be associated with low social seeking. Similarly, this study would also investigate if the avoidance of social stimuli can be attributed to social anxiety, autistic traits or their interactions in those adults who have both high social anxiety and high autistic traits. For more detailed explanations, or if you wish to know the results of the experiment, you are welcome to contact the researcher using the contact details below.

Your details will be kept confidential at all times, maintaining complete anonymity. Raw data will be kept in a locked cabinet and on password-protected computers, which will only be accessible to me and my supervisor. Raw data will be destroyed once I have graduated. In the case of the data being used for academic publication, materials may be kept until five years have passed from the date of publication. At the top of the page you will find your participant number. Please keep this page for your records or make note of your participant number. If you wish to withdraw your data you need to contact the experimenter using the contact details below, and quote your participant number before 2 weeks after the study . No other information is required and you will not be asked to provide a reason.

Feedback on the study will not be possible as the researcher is not clinically trained and the tools which were used are not clinical in nature and are not intended to be used for diagnosis. If there are any concerns, participants might have to speak with a medical professional (e.g. GP). If you have been affected by some of the issues raised in this study, and would like to talk to someone in confidence about it, you may wish to contact the following organisation(s):

DMU Counselling, Mental Health and Wellbeing
Student Gateway (ground floor Gateway House)
T: +44 (0)116 257 7595
E: counselling@dmu.ac.uk
E: mentalhealthadvice@dmu.ac.uk
W: http://www.dmu.ac.uk/dmu-students/the-student-gateway/counselling-mental-health-and-wellbeing/counselling-mental-health-and-wellbeing.aspx

DMU Counselling services offer a range of services aimed at promoting emotional wellbeing and helping DMU students to achieve full potential at DMU. Face-to-face and e-counselling are available.

Samaritans
1A Elmfield Ave Leicester LE2 1RB
T: 0845 790 9090
E: jo@samaritans.org
W: www.samaritans.org
The Samaritans is a registered charity aimed at providing emotional support to anyone in emotional distress, struggling to cope, or at risk of suicide throughout the United Kingdom and, through their telephone helpline, email, writing, or face-to-face services.

Thank you again for your participation.

Researchers contact details: Thujageni Nimalraj
Researchers Email: thujageni.nimalraj@my365.dmu.ac.uk

Supervisor contact details: Dr Indu Dubey
Supervisors Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk

aq_with_stigma.csv:
Everybody has individual differences in their personality traits and ways they behave. Sometimes, people may feel they have experienced stigma, i.e. being shamed or negatively judged, for some of their traits or behaviours.

In this study we would like you to say how much you agree with a series of statements about traits/behaviours, and then how much you feel you have or have not been stigmatised for these traits/behaviours.

When you are rating the stigma, you need to take into account whether you agreed or disagreed with a statement. For example, if you agreed with a statement "I like to eat carrots", then you would need to say how shamed/stigmatised you have been for eating carrots. However, if you disagreed with the statement "I like to eat carrots" you would need to say how much you've been stigmatised for NOT eating carrots.

To help you understand this task, please answer the following question as if you never sing in the rain, and are stigmatised for not singing in the rain.
I like to sing in the rain
How strongly does this statement apply to you?
How much do you feel you have been shamed/stigmatised for this behaviour?

For the following question, imagine that you like to walk barefoot, and are stigmatised for this.



I like to walk barefoot
How strongly does this statement apply to you?
How much do you feel you have been shamed/stigmatised for this behaviour?

autism_self_stigma_scale.csv: How much have you been shamed or stigmatised for the following behaviours?
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually concentrate more on small details rather than the whole picture

I find it difficult to do more than one thing at
once
If there is an interruption, I cannot switch back to what I was doing very quickly.

I find it difficult to ‘read between the lines’ when
someone is talking to me
I do not know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.

procedure_1.csv.text: This experiment works best (and fastest) in Google Chrome. If you are not already on Google Chrome Indu please copy the url in your browser into Google Chrome.

Thank you for participating - you are about to start an eye-tracking task.

In this task we will ask you to look at some dots to train the camera to know where your eyes are looking.

After this we will present you with pairs of images. You can look wherever you like on the screen.

Please look at the cross.
A pair of images will follow. You are free
to look at either image.

Do not move your head,
only use your eyes.
Please take a break before starting the second half of the eyetracking task.

Please look at the cross.
A pair of images will follow. You are free
to look at either image.

Do not move your head,
only use your eyes.
Thank you for completing the previous eye-tracking task, we're about to ask you to rate some images.

procedure_1.csv.instruct_1: How pleasant is the image (1 = very unpleasant; 5 = neutral; 9 = very pleasant)
procedure_1.csv.instruct_2: How excited/jittery does the image make you feel (1 = very bored; 5 = neutral; 9 = very excited)

procedure_1.csv.text: Thank you for rating the images. You are about to start the final task before completing some questionnaires.

In front of you on the screen, there will be 4 decks of cards: A, B, C, and D.

When we begin the game, I want you to select one card at a time by clicking on a card from any deck you choose. Each time you select a card, the computer will tell you that you won some money. I don't know how much money you will win. You will find out as we go along.

Every time you win, the green bar gets bigger. Every so often, when you click on a card, the computer will tell you that you won some money as usual, but then it will say that you lost some money as well. I don't know when you will lose or how much. You will find out as we go along. Every time you lose, the green bar gets smaller.

You are absolutely free to switch from one deck to the other at any time, and as often as you wish. The goal of the game is to win as much money as possible and avoid losing as much money as possible. You won't know when the game will end. Simply keep on playing until the computer stops.

I am going to give you £2000 of credit, the green bar, to start the game. The red bar is a reminder of how much money you borrowed to play the game and how much money you have to pay back before we see whether you won or lost.

The only hint I can give you, and the most important thing to note is this: Out of these four decks of cards, there are some that are worse than others, and to win you should try to stay away from bad decks.

No matter how much you find yourself losing, you can still win the game if you avoid the worst decks. Also note that the computer does not change the order of the cards once the game begins. It does not make you lose at random, or make you lose money based on the last card you picked.
You've completed the game. After repaying your loan, your net winnings are £

borcsok_ethics.csv:
School of Psychology

Earley Gate,
Whiteknights
PO Box 238,
Reading
RG6 6AL,
UK
phone +44 (0)118 378 8523
fax +44 (0)118 378 6715

Title of Study: Investigating attentional biases to neutral and pleasant images: An eye-tracking study

Information & Consent Sheet

Researchers:

Supervisors: Email: Phone:
Dr Anthony Haffey Anthony.Haffey@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850
Dr Lily Fitzgibbon l.t.fitzgibbon@reading.ac.uk 0118 378 8850


Experimenters Email
Rebecca Borcsok r.borcsok@student.reading.ac.uk

You are being invited to take part in some research. Before you decide whether or not to participate, it is important for you to understand why the research is being conducted and what it will involve. Please read the following information carefully.

What is the purpose of the research?

We are conducting research exploring eye movements when viewing neutral or pleasant images. The purpose of the study is to determine if individual differences influence attentional behaviour. Your participation in this study will require one 30-minute session.

Who is carrying out the research?

The data are being collected by Rebecca Borcsok, under the supervision of Dr Anthony Haffey and Dr Lily Fitzgibbon, in the School of Psychology and Clinical Language Sciences at University of Reading. The research has been approved by the School and University ethics committees.

What happens if I agree to take part?

If you agree to take part in this research, you will be asked to take part in a task where you will view matched pairs of images, whilst your eye movements are recorded. You will also be asked to complete a video-game style task, which records your decision-making. After the two tasks, you will also be asked to complete some questionnaires, including some that ask about your alcohol and gambling behaviours. At the end of the study, you will be debriefed on the tasks you have completed and given further information on the aims of the study.

Are there any risks associated with taking part?

One risk of taking part in this study is the issue of confidentiality. To ensure that information about your personal use of alcohol or gambling behaviour is known by to as few members of the research team as possible, this information will be held by Rebecca Borcsok only, until the study is complete. You will be identified by code only during the study, so you cannot be matched with information about alcohol use or gambling. After the study is complete, all identifying information will be removed, and only subject codes (and non-identifying information) would be matched to information about your alcohol use and gambling behaviour.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be kept confidential and securely stored, with only an anonymous number identifying it. Information linking that number to your name will be stored securely and separately from the data you provide us. All identifiable information collected for the project, such as the consent form, will be destroyed after a period of 60 months from the when the completion of the project has elapsed.

An analysis of the information will form part of our report at the end of the study and may be presented to interested parties and published in scientific journals and related media. Note that all information presented in any reports or publications will be anonymous and unidentifiable.

Is participation voluntary and what if I wish to later withdraw?

Taking part in this study is completely voluntary; you may withdraw at any time without having to give any reason. Please feel free to ask any questions that you may have about this study at any point.

What if I have other questions?

If you have further questions about this study, please do not hesitate to contact the student experimenter or supervisors listed above.
I confirm that I have read the information sheet for this study. I have had the opportunity to consider the information, ask questions and have had these answered satisfactorily.
I understand that all personal information will remain confidential to the Investigator and arrangements for the storage and eventual disposal of any identifiable material have been made clear to me.
I understand that participation in this study is voluntary and that I can withdraw at any time without having to give an explanation.
I am happy to proceed with my participation.

phasetypes.webgazer:
This experiment is based on code from the OSF repository https://osf.io/jmz79/ which accompanies the publication "Online webcam-based eye tracking in cognitive science: a first look" by Semmelmann & Weigelt, published in Behavior Research Methods in 2017. Please find the abstract and information about the code, analyses, and data below. This work is intended for scientific use only. Written by Kilian Semmelmann, tolcam@ksemmelm.de, 2017.

Updates by Anthony Haffey (a.haffey@reading.ac.uk) 2020 to make this a task that works on Collector.

Webcam Setup


You can take a short break and move your head. Before continuing, please follow the instructions noted below.

Please turn off your mobile phone and close all other programs and websites. Then carefully read and follow these instructions:


This study consists of multiple five-minute parts with pauses inbetween. After you clicked "start", please avoid moving your head. If you move too much, the calibration can fail and you might not be able to finish the study.

Proceed


Click "Proceed" to move onto the next trial
<
>
0
+
X
no message
phasetypes.setup:
<script>
/*
* From the PEBL battery 
*/
parent.parent.card_lists = [{
    gain: {
      A: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - frequent high losses
      B: 100,   // high gains and high losses (average value of each card is low/negative) - infrequent very high losses
      C: 50,    // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - frequent low losses
      D: 50     // low gains and lower losses (average value is positive) - infrequent moderate/high losses
    },
    
    /*
    * Decks A and C
    */
    // red card signifies a loss
    // black card signifies a gain
    
    /*
    * Decks B and D
    */
    // sometimes get a red card with no associated loss (red has no meaning)
    
    
    loss: {
      A: [0,0,150,0,300,0,200,0,250,350,
          0,350,0,250,200,0,300,150,0,0,
          0,300,0,350,0,200,250,150,0,0,
          350,200,250,0,0,0,150,300,0,0],
      B: [-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,1250,0, 
          -1,-1,0,1250,0,-1,-1,0,0,0,
          1250,0,-1,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0,
          -1,1250,0,-1,0,-1,0,-1,0,0],
      C: [0,0,50,0,50,0,50,0,50,50, 
          0,25,75,0,0,0,25,75,0,50, 
          0,0,0,50,25,50,0,0,75,50,
          0,0,0,25,25,0,75,0,50,75],
      D: [-1,0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,0,0,250,
          -1,-1,0,0,-1,0,0,0,-1,250,
          0,-1,0,0,-1,-1,-1,0,250,0,
          0,-1,0,-1,250,-1,0,0,-1,0] 
    }
  }]
  
parent.parent.earnings = 2000
parent.parent.borrowed = 0

Trial.set_timer(function(){
  Trial.submit();
},0);
</script>

cam_info:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher/Student: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk | Supervisor/Chief investigator: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

We would like to invite you to take part in a research study about factors which may play a role in anxiety in adults with and without autism. Before you begin, we would like you to understand why the research is being done and what it involves for you.

What is the purpose of this study?

I am a postgraduate student at the University of Nottingham studying for an MSc in Mental Health research and practice. I am conducting this study for my research project which will allow me to complete and gain my MSc qualification. The aim of this research is to investigate intolerance of uncertainty, sensory sensitivity, and anxiety in adults who do and do not identify as having autism. Specifically, I aim to investigate how varying levels of intolerance of uncertainty, and sensory sensitivity may (or may not) influence anxiety, and how this may differ between adults with and without autism. We cannot promise the study will help you but the information we get from this study may help us gain a deeper understanding of the role(s) intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity may play in anxiety, both in typical and autism-identifying adults. This could help in development of targeted intervention for co-occurring anxiety in autism.

Why have I been invited?

I am asking adults (over 18 years old) to complete this online study. You have been identified because you responded to an earlier invitation to take part in this research. Ideally, I am hoping to recruit around 140 participants for this study (70 participants who identify as autistic and 70 who do not).

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part, you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form when directed to the online study. You may change your mind about being involved at any time or decline to discuss a particular question. You are free to withdraw at any point before or during the study without giving a reason. You may also withdraw after the study, but if you wish to do so this must be done within 3 days following completion. If you wish to withdraw, please contact the student researcher with your participant code (which you will be assigned when you do the study), and all of your data will then be removed. To safeguard your rights, we will use the minimum personally-identifiable information possible. There will also be an opportunity to enter a prize draw for taking part in the study of £25, and there will be 8 prizes available. If you wish to enter, you will need to provide the researcher with your email address so that you can be contacted if you win.

What will I be asked to do?

If you decide to take part, you will be asked to complete an online study. Before beginning the study, you will be asked to read and sign a consent form. You will then be provided with a short form to provide demographic information such as your gender and age. You will not be required to disclose your name or personal information; you will have a unique identification code generated in the event your data needs to be accessed later should you wish to withdraw. You will then be required to complete the study. You will be presented with self-report questionnaires regarding autistic traits, anxiety, sensory sensitivity, and intolerance of uncertainty. Following this, you will be required to complete 2 interactive behavioural tasks; one will be a “sensory sensitivity” task, the other will be an “intolerance of uncertainty” task. The study may take up to 90 minutes, therefore collection of data may be split into two or three shorter sessions to work through all the questionnaires/tasks.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be used by the researcher to complete their postgraduate research project. A summary of the study’s findings will be available upon request following completion of the study in September 2022. Data belonging to anybody who agrees to participate in this research will remain strictly anonymous. When your data is recorded, you will be assigned a unique ID code to correspond to your study responses; none of your personal or identifiable information will be exposed. Your data will not be shared with any third parties, and your identity and responses will not be directly or indirectly identifiable from any research findings presented in the final report. All data will be collected and stored in accordance with the University of Nottingham’s Code of Conduct and Research Ethics and data protection regulations. Following completion of this project, any raw data collected for the purpose of this research will be securely stored by the University for 7 years. Data will not be stored anywhere else; after this time all data will be appropriately removed. If you enter the prize draw, your email address will be protected and securely stored separate to any data obtained from the study, and it will be removed as soon as the winners of the draw have been contacted.

Are there any possible disadvantages or risks in taking part?

We believe there are no known risks associated with this research study; however, as with any online activity the risk of a breach is always possible. We will do everything possible to ensure your answers in this study will remain anonymous. We don’t expect there to be any disadvantages or risks to taking part. In the unlikely event that it does give rise to any concerns for you, we advise you to discuss these with a trained professional, such as your general practitioner. Other areas to get support include the Samaritans, contactable on 116 123, or Mind, a mental health charity, contactable on 0300 123 3393. There is also the National Autistic Society; they do not have a direct helpline, but you will be able to find contact details for support and enquiries at https://www.autism.org.uk/what-we-do/help-and-support, where you can also find contact details for support groups in your local area.

Data Protection

We will follow ethical and legal practice and all information will be handled in confidence. Under UK Data Protection laws the University is the Data Controller (legally responsible for the data security) and the Chief Investigator of this study (named above) is the Data Custodian (manages access to the data). This means we are responsible for looking after your information and using it properly. Your rights to access, change or move your information are limited as we need to manage your information in specific ways to comply with certain laws and for the research to be reliable and accurate. To safeguard your rights we will use the minimum personally–identifiable information possible. You can find out more about how we use your information and to read our privacy notice at: https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/utilities/privacy.aspx We would like your permission to use anonymised data in future studies, and to share our research data (e.g. in online databases) with other researchers in other Universities and organisations both inside and outside the European Union. This would be used for research in health and social care. Sharing research data is important to allow peer scrutiny, re-use (and therefore avoiding duplication of research) and to understand the bigger picture in particular areas of research. All personal information that could identify you will be removed or changed before information is shared with other researchers or results are made public. The raw data collected for the study will be saved on the RedCap storage platform for University of Nottingham and University of Reading and will be accessible to the named researchers and collaborators. They may also be looked at by authorised people from regulatory organisations to check that the study is being carried out correctly. All will have a duty of confidentiality to you as a research participant and we will do our best to meet this duty. At the end of the project, all raw data will be kept securely by the University under the terms of its data protection policy after which it will be disposed of securely. The data will not be kept elsewhere. If you have any questions or concerns, please don’t hesitate to ask. We can be contacted before and after your participation at the email addresses above.

What if there is a problem?

If you have any queries or complaints, please contact the student’s supervisor/chief investigator in the first instance. If this does not resolve your query, please write to the Administrator to the Division of Psychiatry & Applied Psychology’s Research Ethics Sub-Committee adrian.pantry@nottingam.ac.uk who will pass your query to the Chair of the Committee. If you remain unhappy and wish to complain formally, you should then contact the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences Ethics Committee Administrator, Faculty Hub, Medicine and Health Sciences, E41, E Floor, Medical School, Queen’s Medical Centre Campus, Nottingham University Hospitals, Nottingham, NG7 2UH or via E-mail: FMHS-ResearchEthics@nottingham.ac.uk
I have read the information sheet and I am happy to continue

Title of project: Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of 
anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk |
Supervisor: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, 
University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk
Please select the following statements if you agree with them. Please feel free to withdraw at any point.
1. Have you read and understood the Participant Information?

2. Do you agree to take part in an experiment investigating intolerance of uncertainty and 
sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in adults with and without autism?

3. Do you know how to contact the researcher if you have questions
about this study?

4. Do you understand that you are free to withdraw from the study
without giving a reason within 3 days following completion, and that after 
this time it may not be technically possible to withdraw your data?

5. Do you give permission for your data from this study to be shared with 
other researchers in the future provided that your anonymity is protected?

6. Do you understand that non-identifiable data from this study including 
quotations might be used in academic research reports or publications?
7. I confirm that I am 18 years old or over.

If you would like a summary of the research findings please insert your email address in 
this text box.

If you would like to enter the prize draw to win £25, please insert your email address in this 
text box.

Uncertainty stops me from having a strong opinion.
Being uncertain means that a person is disorganized.
It's unfair having no guarantees in life.
My mind can't be relaxed if I don't know what will happen tomorrow.
Uncertainty makes me uneasy, anxious, or stressed.
It frustrates me not having all the information I need.
Uncertainty keeps me from living a full life.
One should always look ahead so as to avoid surprises.
A small unforeseen event can spoil everything, even with the best planning.

Being uncertain means that I am not first rate.

When I am uncertain, I can't function very well.
Unlike me, others seem to know where they are going with their lives.
Uncertainty makes me vulnerable, unhappy, or sad.
I always want to know what the future has in store for me.
I can't stand being taken by surprise.
The smallest doubt can stop me from acting.
I should be able to organize everything in advance.
Being uncertain means that I lack confidence.
I think it's unfair that other people seem to be sure about their future.
Uncertainty keeps me from sleeping soundly.
I must get away from all uncertain situations.
The ambiguities in life stress me.
I can't stand being undecided about my future.

cam_debrief:
Debrief form

Thank you so much for participating in this study. This study aims to explore how worry may affect the day to day behaviour and choices we make. Literature suggests that the worry experienced by people with autism might be different from worry experienced by other people. It is proposed that social difficulties, sensory sensitivity, or uncertainty might be the significant cause of worry for people with autism but not those without autism. In this study, we are exploring if these factors can reliably predict worry in people with autism but not in people with worry without autism. We believe this study would help shaping differential interventions for people experiencing different kinds of worry. If you would like to know more about the project, please contact the lead investigator.

If you would like to withdraw your consent, please contact the lead investigator in next 3 days. After 3 days of the participation we will not be able to delete your data.

Contact for Further Information
Dr Indu Dubey
Lecturer in Psychology
Room 0.35, Hawthorn Building
Division of Psychology,
School of Applied Social Sciences,
De Montfort University,
Leicester,
UK
Phone: 0116 366 4401
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk

cam_info:
PARTICIPANT INFORMATION SHEET

Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher/Student: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk | Supervisor/Chief investigator: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk

We would like to invite you to take part in a research study about factors which may play a role in anxiety in adults with and without autism. Before you begin, we would like you to understand why the research is being done and what it involves for you.

What is the purpose of this study?

I am a postgraduate student at the University of Nottingham studying for an MSc in Mental Health research and practice. I am conducting this study for my research project which will allow me to complete and gain my MSc qualification. The aim of this research is to investigate intolerance of uncertainty, sensory sensitivity, and anxiety in adults who do and do not identify as having autism. Specifically, I aim to investigate how varying levels of intolerance of uncertainty, and sensory sensitivity may (or may not) influence anxiety, and how this may differ between adults with and without autism. We cannot promise the study will help you but the information we get from this study may help us gain a deeper understanding of the role(s) intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity may play in anxiety, both in typical and autism-identifying adults. This could help in development of targeted intervention for co-occurring anxiety in autism.

Why have I been invited?

I am asking adults (over 18 years old) to complete this online study. You have been identified because you responded to an earlier invitation to take part in this research. Ideally, I am hoping to recruit around 140 participants for this study (70 participants who identify as autistic and 70 who do not).

Do I have to take part?

It is up to you to decide whether or not to take part. If you do decide to take part, you will be given this information sheet to keep and be asked to sign a consent form when directed to the online study. You may change your mind about being involved at any time or decline to discuss a particular question. You are free to withdraw at any point before or during the study without giving a reason. You may also withdraw after the study, but if you wish to do so this must be done within 3 days following completion. If you wish to withdraw, please contact the student researcher with your participant code (which you will be assigned when you do the study), and all of your data will then be removed. To safeguard your rights, we will use the minimum personally-identifiable information possible. There will also be an opportunity to enter a prize draw for taking part in the study of £25, and there will be 8 prizes available. If you wish to enter, you will need to provide the researcher with your email address so that you can be contacted if you win.

What will I be asked to do?

If you decide to take part, you will be asked to complete an online study. Before beginning the study, you will be asked to read and sign a consent form. You will then be provided with a short form to provide demographic information such as your gender and age. You will not be required to disclose your name or personal information; you will have a unique identification code generated in the event your data needs to be accessed later should you wish to withdraw. You will then be required to complete the study. You will be presented with self-report questionnaires regarding autistic traits, anxiety, sensory sensitivity, and intolerance of uncertainty. Following this, you will be required to complete 2 interactive behavioural tasks; one will be a “sensory sensitivity” task, the other will be an “intolerance of uncertainty” task. The study may take up to 90 minutes, therefore collection of data may be split into two or three shorter sessions to work through all the questionnaires/tasks.

What will happen to the information I provide?

Your data will be used by the researcher to complete their postgraduate research project. A summary of the study’s findings will be available upon request following completion of the study in September 2022. Data belonging to anybody who agrees to participate in this research will remain strictly anonymous. When your data is recorded, you will be assigned a unique ID code to correspond to your study responses; none of your personal or identifiable information will be exposed. Your data will not be shared with any third parties, and your identity and responses will not be directly or indirectly identifiable from any research findings presented in the final report. All data will be collected and stored in accordance with the University of Nottingham’s Code of Conduct and Research Ethics and data protection regulations. Following completion of this project, any raw data collected for the purpose of this research will be securely stored by the University for 7 years. Data will not be stored anywhere else; after this time all data will be appropriately removed. If you enter the prize draw, your email address will be protected and securely stored separate to any data obtained from the study, and it will be removed as soon as the winners of the draw have been contacted.

Are there any possible disadvantages or risks in taking part?

We believe there are no known risks associated with this research study; however, as with any online activity the risk of a breach is always possible. We will do everything possible to ensure your answers in this study will remain anonymous. We don’t expect there to be any disadvantages or risks to taking part. In the unlikely event that it does give rise to any concerns for you, we advise you to discuss these with a trained professional, such as your general practitioner. Other areas to get support include the Samaritans, contactable on 116 123, or Mind, a mental health charity, contactable on 0300 123 3393. There is also the National Autistic Society; they do not have a direct helpline, but you will be able to find contact details for support and enquiries at https://www.autism.org.uk/what-we-do/help-and-support, where you can also find contact details for support groups in your local area.

Data Protection

We will follow ethical and legal practice and all information will be handled in confidence. Under UK Data Protection laws the University is the Data Controller (legally responsible for the data security) and the Chief Investigator of this study (named above) is the Data Custodian (manages access to the data). This means we are responsible for looking after your information and using it properly. Your rights to access, change or move your information are limited as we need to manage your information in specific ways to comply with certain laws and for the research to be reliable and accurate. To safeguard your rights we will use the minimum personally–identifiable information possible. You can find out more about how we use your information and to read our privacy notice at: https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/utilities/privacy.aspx We would like your permission to use anonymised data in future studies, and to share our research data (e.g. in online databases) with other researchers in other Universities and organisations both inside and outside the European Union. This would be used for research in health and social care. Sharing research data is important to allow peer scrutiny, re-use (and therefore avoiding duplication of research) and to understand the bigger picture in particular areas of research. All personal information that could identify you will be removed or changed before information is shared with other researchers or results are made public. The raw data collected for the study will be saved on the RedCap storage platform for University of Nottingham and University of Reading and will be accessible to the named researchers and collaborators. They may also be looked at by authorised people from regulatory organisations to check that the study is being carried out correctly. All will have a duty of confidentiality to you as a research participant and we will do our best to meet this duty. At the end of the project, all raw data will be kept securely by the University under the terms of its data protection policy after which it will be disposed of securely. The data will not be kept elsewhere. If you have any questions or concerns, please don’t hesitate to ask. We can be contacted before and after your participation at the email addresses above.

What if there is a problem?

If you have any queries or complaints, please contact the student’s supervisor/chief investigator in the first instance. If this does not resolve your query, please write to the Administrator to the Division of Psychiatry & Applied Psychology’s Research Ethics Sub-Committee adrian.pantry@nottingam.ac.uk who will pass your query to the Chair of the Committee. If you remain unhappy and wish to complain formally, you should then contact the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences Ethics Committee Administrator, Faculty Hub, Medicine and Health Sciences, E41, E Floor, Medical School, Queen’s Medical Centre Campus, Nottingham University Hospitals, Nottingham, NG7 2UH or via E-mail: FMHS-ResearchEthics@nottingham.ac.uk

Title of project: Exploring intolerance of uncertainty and sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of 
anxiety in autistic and neurotypical adults.

Researcher: Jasmine Saunders msxjs23@nottingham.ac.uk |
Supervisor: Dr Indu Dubey indu.dubey2@nottingham.ac.uk | Collaborator: Dr Anthony Haffey, Lecturer, School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences, 
University of Reading a.haffey@reading.ac.uk
Please select the following statements if you agree with them. Please feel free to withdraw at any point.
1. Have you read and understood the Participant Information?

2. Do you agree to take part in an experiment investigating intolerance of uncertainty and 
sensory sensitivity as mechanisms of anxiety in adults with and without autism?

3. Do you know how to contact the researcher if you have questions
about this study?

4. Do you understand that you are free to withdraw from the study
without giving a reason within 3 days following completion, and that after 
this time it may not be technically possible to withdraw your data?

5. Do you give permission for your data from this study to be shared with 
other researchers in the future provided that your anonymity is protected?

6. Do you understand that non-identifiable data from this study including 
quotations might be used in academic research reports or publications?
7. I confirm that I am 18 years old or over.

If you would like a summary of the research findings please insert your email address in 
this text box.

If you would like to enter the prize draw to win £25, please insert your email address in this 
text box.

autism_quotient: Choose one response that best describes how strongly each item applies to you:
I prefer to do things with others rather than on my own.
I prefer to do things the same way over and over again.
If I try to imagine something, I find it very easy to create a picture in my mind.
I frequently get so strongly absorbed in one thing that I lose sight of other things.
I often notice small sounds when others do not.
I usually notice car number plates or similar strings of information.
Other people frequently tell me that what I've said is impolite, even though I think it is polite.
When I'm reading a story, I can easily imagine what the characters might look like.
In a social group, I can easily keep track of several different people's conversations.
I tend to notice details that others do not.
I would rather go to a library than a party.
I find making up stories easy.
I find myself drawn more strongly to people than to things.
I tend to have very strong interests which I get upset about if I can't pursue.
When I talk, it isn't always easy for others to get a word in edgeways.
When I'm reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the characters' intentions.
I don't particularly enjoy reading fiction.
I find it hard to make new friends.
I notice patterns in things all the time.
I would rather go to the theatre than a museum.
It does not upset me if my daily routine is disturbed.
I frequently find that I don't know how to keep a conversation going.
I find it easy to 'read between the lines' when someone is talking to me.
I usually concentrate more on the whole picture, rather than the small details.
I am not very good at remembering phone numbers.
I don't usually notice small changes in a situation, or a person's appearance.
I know how to tell if someone listening to me is getting bored.
I find it easy to do more than one thing at once.
When I talk on the phone, I'm not sure when it's my turn to speak.
I am often the last to understand the point of a joke.
I find it easy to work out what someone is thinking or feeling just by looking at their face.
If there is an interruption, I can switch back to what I was doing very quickly.
I am good at social chit-chat.
People often tell me that I keep going on and on about the same thing.
When I was young, I used to enjoy playing games involving pretending with other children.
I like to collect information about categories of things (e.g. types of car, types of bird, types of train, types of plant, etc.).
I find it difficult to imagine what it would be like to be someone else.
I like to plan any activities I participate in carefully.
I find it difficult to work out people's intentions.
I am not very good at remembering people's date of birth.
I find it very easy to play games with children that involve pretending.

cam_debrief:
Debrief form

Thank you so much for participating in this study. This study aims to explore how worry may affect the day to day behaviour and choices we make. Literature suggests that the worry experienced by people with autism might be different from worry experienced by other people. It is proposed that social difficulties, sensory sensitivity, or uncertainty might be the significant cause of worry for people with autism but not those without autism. In this study, we are exploring if these factors can reliably predict worry in people with autism but not in people with worry without autism. We believe this study would help shaping differential interventions for people experiencing different kinds of worry. If you would like to know more about the project, please contact the lead investigator.

If you would like to withdraw your consent, please contact the lead investigator in next 3 days. After 3 days of the participation we will not be able to delete your data.

Contact for Further Information
Dr Indu Dubey
Lecturer in Psychology
Room 0.35, Hawthorn Building
Division of Psychology,
School of Applied Social Sciences,
De Montfort University,
Leicester,
UK
Phone: 0116 366 4401
Email: indu.dubey@dmu.ac.uk
I understand these instructions and am happy to continue
highly_sensitive_person_scale .csv:
Answer each question according to the way you personally feel, using the following scale:
1=Not at All	     4=Moderately	       7=Extremely
Are you easily overwhelmed by strong sensory input?
Do you seem to be aware of subtleties in your environment?
Do other people's moods affect you?
Do you tend to be more sensitive to pain?
Do you find yourself needing to withdraw during busy days, into bed or into a darkened room or any place where you can have some privacy and relief from stimulation?
Are you particularly sensitive to the effects of caffeine?
Are you easily overwhelmed by things like bright lights, strong smells, coarse fabrics, or sirens close by?
Do you have a rich, complex inner life?
Are you made uncomfortable by loud noises?
Are you deeply moved by the arts or music?
Does your nervous system sometimes feel so frazzled that you just have to go off by yourself?
Do you get rattled when you have a lot to do in a short amount of time?
When people are uncomfortable in a physical environment do you tend to know what needs to be done to make it more comfortable (like changing the lighting or the seating)?
Are you annoyed when people try to get you to do too many things at once?
Do you try hard to avoid making mistakes or forgetting things?
Do you make a point to avoid violent movies and TV shows?
Do you become unpleasantly aroused when a lot is going on around you?
Does being very hungry create a strong reaction in you, disrupting your concentration or mood?
Do changes in your life shake you up?
Do you notice and enjoy delicate or fine scents, tastes, sounds, works of art?
Do you find it unpleasant to have a lot going on at once?
Do you make it a high priority to arrange your life to avoid upsetting or overwhelming situations?
Are you bothered by intense stimuli, like loud noises or chaotic scenes?
When you must compete or be observed while performing a task, do you become so nervous or shaky that you do much worse than you would otherwise?
When you were a child, did parents or teachers seem to see you as sensitive or shy?
